user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_socket_set_nodelay_:
```c
int
MHD_socket_set_nodelay_ (MHD_socket sock,
                         bool on)
{
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  {
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
    /* Disable Nagle's algorithm for normal buffering */
    return setsockopt (sock,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) ((on) ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (on_val));
  }
#else
  (void) sock;
  return 0;
#endif /* TCP_NODELAY */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  {
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
    /* Disable Nagle's algorithm for normal buffering */
    return setsockopt (sock,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) ((on) ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (on_val));
  }
#else
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code in the #ifdef branch is compiled only when TCP_NODELAY is defined and contains a return; when it is not defined the #else branch (return 0) is compiled instead. Both possible translation units contain only reachable code — a violation would arise if, in the same compiled branch, statements appeared after an unconditional return (i.e. code that can never be executed), but that is not the case here.
